坦率街头摄影：改善图像的 19 个技巧首先出现在数码摄影学校上。它的作者是詹姆斯·马赫。

;

坦率街头摄影：改善图像的 19 个技巧首先出现在数码摄影学校上。它的作者是詹姆斯·马赫。

本文于 James Maher 和 Jaymes Dempsey 的贡献下于 2023 年 4 月更新。

偷拍街头摄影非常有趣，但也可能相当困难，尤其是对于街拍新手来说。

在这篇文章中，我分享了我最喜欢的 19 个技巧和策略，以提升你的街拍街拍水平。这些是我在十多年的街头摄影中总结出来的技巧——我保证，如果你仔细应用它们，你最终会得到很好的结果。

让我们开始吧。

1. 轻装出行，携带最少的装备

许多街头摄影新手都使用数码单反相机和中焦变焦镜头，虽然使用如此笨重的设备进行街头摄影没什么问题，但减轻您的负担会带来巨大的不同。你会有更多的精力，你的协调性会更好，你会更快，更愿意探索。您还可以在不方便携带大型相机的情况下进行拍摄。

那么我推荐什么类型的装备呢？

首先，考虑更紧凑的街头摄影相机。无反光镜型号——尤其是APS-C 和微型三分之四选项——更小、更轻，而且它们看起来对你拍摄的人来说不那么令人生畏。

如果您确实想坚持使用 DSLR，请考虑使用小型定焦镜头，例如 35 毫米或 50 毫米。例如，50mm f/1.8 将比标准变焦小得多。它也将非常便宜并提供高质量的光学器件。

请注意，定焦镜头会将您限制在特定的焦距范围内，但这种限制实际上是相当自由的。通过坚持使用 35 毫米或 50 毫米（大多数街头摄影师最喜欢的两个焦距），您将很快学会了解镜头的视角，并且在将相机举到眼前之前，您将能够更好地可视化镜头。

2. 有效地握住相机

速度是街头摄影的关键，你如何握持相机可以让世界变得不同。我喜欢将相机带绕在手腕上而不是脖子上。通过这种方式操作相机会更快、更容易，而且如果需要，您还可以轻松地从臀部进行拍摄（请参阅下一节！）。

当走在街上时，我通常以 45 度角将相机放在我面前，介于垂直和水平之间，手指放在扳机上。这样，如果发生自发的事情，我可以轻松地将相机调到正确的位置，而不会告知拍摄对象我要拍摄它们。

3. 握紧相机

拍摄时，尽可能将相机握在手中并保持注意力集中。如果你让它挂在你的脖子或手腕上，那么当一个令人惊奇的时刻发生时，你将必须找到并抓住相机，然后再将它放在你的眼前。

这不仅会导致您错过精彩的镜头，而且还会更加明显。始终拿着相机确实是捕捉街拍图像的最不显眼的方法。

另外，尽量将相机保持在较高的位置。然后，当您拍摄图像时，您根本不需要移动手臂！

4. 用你的主题填充画面（不要害怕裁剪！）

我对街头摄影师最大的批评是，当我看到一张主题非常有趣的照片时，摄影师却决定拍摄整条街道，让本来应该是整张照片的东西变成画面的一小部分。用重要的内容填充框架并剪掉其他所有内容。留一些想象空间。

此外，使用定焦镜头和快速移动的拍摄对象，您并不总是能够处于完美位置或即时捕捉完美角度。不要害怕事后裁剪或改善角度。街头摄影与风景摄影有很大不同，风景摄影中你总是能够在拍摄之前计划好图像的各个方面。您应该习惯使用裁剪工具，即使它只是为了进行轻微的修正。

5.从臀部射击

除非您有一个非常小的测距仪，否则现实情况是，如果您不必将相机举过胸部或通过取景器观看，那么在不被别人注意到的情况下拍摄照片会容易得多。

将相机绑在手腕上从臀部拍摄的优点是它实际上成为了手臂的延伸。你不必向前方射击，如果需要，可以向侧面甚至向后射击。它可以让您在没有人注意到的情况下将镜头融入场景中。您可以用双手或一只手握住相机从臀部拍摄，但一只手可以让您更自由地瞄准任何方向。

只需将手臂伸直放在身体两侧，然后将相机向上倾斜，无论场景发生在哪个方向。然后，如果需要，您可以抬起手臂或稍微弯曲肘部以获得准确的框架，但要谨慎。

6.尝试低对角

臀部拍摄的另一个优点是你可以从很低的角度捕捉人物。我通常更喜欢特写和低角度的偷拍摄影，因为它可以拉长人物并使拍摄对象充满画面。显然并非所有情况都如此，但很多时候这是我个人的偏好。

轻微的对角可以非常令人愉悦，尤其是对于垂直肖像。这个角度为照片注入了一些能量，让你可以捕捉到更多的周围环境。它为眼睛进入照片创造了一个线索，并将其保持在那里，在拍摄对象和周围环境之间来回跳动。

7. 准备好快速更改设置

我经常用手动模式拍摄街拍，因为我喜欢在拍摄这些类型的照片之前先调整曝光。当拍摄特写镜头时，你永远不知道相机将如何解读情况，这通常会导致大量混乱的曝光，除非你完全控制曝光设置。

但在街上手动拍摄可能需要一些时间来适应。如果您突然从阳光明媚的街道转到阴凉的街道，那么您必须记住更改设置。我通常会在脑海中保留阳光明媚和阴暗的一般曝光设置，并在它们之间来回切换。

但如果突然发生什么事情呢？假设您正走在一条阳光明媚的街道上，设置设置得很好，突然您向右看，发现一辆非常黑暗的货车里有几个锁匠，其中一个昏倒了，另一个正要点燃香烟。这一刻即将发生：

好吧，在这种情况下，我很快切换到相机上的光圈优先，我预设了低光圈值。即使您会损失一些景深，您也可以让它在极亮或极暗的情况下以足够快的相应快门速度工作。您也可以通过快门速度（通过快门优先模式）来做到这一点。

8.提高ISO

如果您参加摄影研讨会或参加摄影课程，您可能遇到过标准建议：保持ISO尽可能低。

然而，虽然高 ISO 会产生令人不快的噪点效果，但现代相机提供了非常令人印象深刻的高 ISO 功能；你通常可以在 1600 和 3200 的 ISO 下拍摄，噪音最小，这就是为什么在我看来，你不应该害怕提高 ISO 。

我通常在阳光下使用 ISO 400、浅色下使用 ISO 800、深色下使用 ISO 1600、黄昏下使用 ISO 3200、夜间使用 ISO 6400 拍摄街拍照片。对于入门级或不太先进的相机，我会将其降低一级（即，在阳光下拍摄 ISO 200，在进行街头夜间摄影时高达 ISO 3200）。

你看，高 ISO 给你带来了巨大的优势。即使在低光照条件下，它也可以让您使用较快的快门速度，这意味着您可以手持拍摄，可以冻结运动，并且可以使用小光圈来最大化景深。

（为什么需要深景深？一方面，如果您无法专注于拍摄对象，您仍然可以获得足够清晰的镜头。另外，它可以让您在单个构图中保持多个拍摄对象清晰，这是一种为您的坦率图像添加背景和复杂性的好方法。）

9.尝试区域对焦

区域对焦是将相机转为手动对焦模式，将其预先对焦到大约 8-10 英尺的距离，然后在拍摄对象处于相机清晰度范围内时捕捉它们。使用具有中小光圈（例如 f/8 至 f/16）的广角镜头更容易做到这一点，这样图像的焦点区域就会更大。请记住，这是一项可以提高的技能 - 许多摄影师甚至在 f/2 时也能很好地进行区域对焦。

您可以在此处阅读有关区域对焦的更多信息，虽然一开始学习有点困难，但您很快就会变得更好。这种对焦方式的主要好处是，您不再需要将自动对焦锁定在拍摄对象上。这可以让您在拍摄时更加自发，并且可以让您有更多的时间来拍照。反过来，这将使您能够更好地捕捉那些非常快速的移动时刻。

最重要的是，它会让你比使用自动对焦更加坦率。由于您不必将相机直接对准拍摄对象来锁定焦点，也不必通过取景器查看以确保对焦正确，因此您可以更加不引人注目。这将使您能够从臀部开始射击，并且仍然知道您的射击将是锐利的。

10. 选择一个地点并等待

街头摄影师通常只是拿起相机，四处走走，探索——但不断地行走可能会给自己带来伤害。您会错过需要一点耐心的镜头（这些镜头通常比您四处走动时得到的镜头更好）。

因此，不要一直步行，而是走到外面——当你找到一个有希望的位置时，停留一段时间，等待事情发生。

通过选择地点，您可以给一个神奇的时刻充足的时间来实现——如果您仔细选择了地点，您将能够将主题兴趣和良好的背景结合起来，以获得一流的结果。毕竟，当正确的地点与有趣的时刻融合在一起时，一张精彩的照片就会出现。

此外，如果你埋伏等待，你会更快地注意到周围的环境。您不会专注于步行，因此您可以花时间扫描人流。

另外，人们会进入你的场景，而不是相反。这可能看起来没什么大不了的，但根据我的经验，它使整个坦率街拍的做法变得更容易，也更少对抗性。

最后一点：如果您想在不被人注意的情况下进行坦率的街头摄影，请确保在拍摄对象走进图像之前将相机举到眼睛附近。然后在拍摄对象离开场景时保持相机向上。这样，看起来就像您只是在拍摄背景一样！

11. 追逐行动

对你来说，最终在各种情况下拍摄很重要，从不太繁忙到非常拥挤，但特别是当你在学习时，去发生很多动作的地方。去展会，在繁忙的时候出去，在繁忙的角落拍摄。发生的事情越多，你就越会被忽视，你就越不会被别人注意到。这将对您的舒适度有很大帮助。

此外，如果你在一个繁忙的地区，你周围经常会有各种有趣的元素，所以你不需要移动太多。这样，您将能够花更多的精力观察周围的环境，等待美好的时刻发生。当然，这并不意味着您在步行和探索时不应该拍照，只是您应该尽量留在繁忙的地区。

12. 做一名演员（不要目光接触）

作为一名街头摄影师，你可以从表演中受益匪浅。你可能会扮演一个神智不清的游客，被街对面发生的事情所困扰，或者可能是一个迷路的人，不得不停下来冷静一下，但你肯定不是那种看起来像是要走的人。拍个照。

我喜欢表现得就像我在做白日梦一样，只是被周围的环境隔开，看着与我想要拍摄的方向相反的方向。我会让我的路径以正确的方式与主题相交，然后停下来，就像我正在集中注意力或好像我看到了一些有趣的东西。我的身体通常会与拍摄对象成一定角度，而我的相机则位于我的臀部，向上指向拍摄对象。然后我拍了一两张照片然后离开那里，就像什么都没发生一样。

但最重要的是，永远不要将头直接指向拍摄对象，或者上帝保佑，进行眼神交流！目光接触几乎是一种进化，会让人们立即注意到你。即使只有一瞬间，它也会毁掉你的掩护。相反，尝试“看穿这个人”。

13.避免拍照

与最后一点类似，移动相机的方式可以在保持情况坦率方面发挥重要作用。大多数摄影师都会做一件事，称为“相机快照”，即他们在拍摄图像后立即本能地将相机从眼睛上移开。

当然，有些镜头你拍得太快以至于人们不会注意到。但在其他时刻，当人们注意到你时，这通常会暴露出你正在给他们拍照的事实。

相反，拍照时请将相机放在您的眼前。然后将相机移开，就像您在他们旁边拍照一样，然后慢慢地将相机从您的眼睛上移开。

14. 如果有人阻止你，知道该说什么

不管你怎么看，街头摄影本质上都是令人不舒服的——如果不是为了你，也为了你正在拍摄的人。有些拍摄对象会因相机而感到受宠若惊，但另一些拍摄对象则会感到困惑甚至烦恼。

如果你从事街头摄影的时间足够长，即使你采用低调的方式，你最终也会遇到质疑你的人。他们甚至可能会生气。

那么当这种情况发生时你会说什么？

当有人问你是否拍了他们的照片时，坦白承认并告诉他们你在做什么。与他们交谈并解释为什么你觉得他们很有趣。我总是随身携带一张名片，如果他们通过电子邮件向我索要照片，我会主动将照片发送给我。

无论发生什么，脸上始终保持微笑。如果有人看起来很生气，没有必要进行防御或生气。在街上拍照是你的合法权利（当然，取决于你在哪里拍照），但你不需要解释这一点，至少一开始不需要。这并不是立即提出的最佳选择，因为这可能会让人们更加愤怒。

相反，想办法化解这种情况。告诉他们你并不是故意让他们感到不舒服。多年来，当我认为有必要时，我会主动提出删除几张照片。

但是，如果您小心的话，您不会遇到很多问题。我已经频繁拍摄了15年，我只能回忆起一两个不舒服的情况。

15. 不要害怕尝试（甚至奇怪）

街头摄影是捕捉你周围发生的生活和文化。它不一定是为了美丽，也不一定是为了创造在 Instagram 上广受喜爱的“标准”街拍。

所以表达自己。拍摄你感兴趣的东西。捕捉独特的主题。您并不总是需要拍摄最漂亮或最漂亮的照片；相反，尝试创造一些让观众思考或让他们失去平衡的东西，即使它很奇怪。为自己拍摄图像，无论是否有些人无法理解或无法立即喜欢它们。

请记住：取悦所有人不是你的工作。拍一张好照片是你的工作。

并且要自发。对于其他形式的摄影，您可以成为每个细节的完美主义者。虽然在街头摄影时以这种方式思考也很重要，但你的许多决定都是在一瞬间做出的。放自己走。每当你觉得有可能形成一个强烈的形象时，即使你不确定，也应该去尝试。其中许多照片都会失败，但其中一些最终将成为您拍摄过的最好的照片。

16.尝试断断续续的步

有时，完全停止并不是一种选择。它看起来太明显了。但同时你必须完全停下来拍照。无论你的快门有多快，如果你在拍照时稍微移动，那么它可能会被毁掉。

所以有一个动作叫结巴步（你能看出来我是篮球迷吗？）。它基本上只是全速前进的一个非常快速的停止，几乎就像你在运动中冻结了一秒钟。对于任何真正关注的人来说，这可能看起来有点荒谬，但它发生得太快以至于没有人会注意到。一旦您尝试过，您就会明白我在说什么，并且需要一些练习才能习惯。

17.接受不完美

对于下一张照片，因为我希望将相机焦点放在 NUTS 街头小贩摊位上（以强调这群争论的游客的“疯狂”品质），这意味着我无法让前景中的人成为焦点。非常锋利。这与地域有关，有时你必须做出一些牺牲。在这种情况下，我认为它有效，但仅限于黑白。

作为一名街头摄影师，我比很多人更不害怕模糊和颗粒。现实情况是，它并不总是明亮的，你需​​要足够快的快门速度，而且你没有使用三脚架的奢侈。您经常会遇到一些模糊、轻微的柔焦或高 ISO 造成的颗粒问题。

（另外，这只是我个人的意见，但我认为这些类型的照片在黑白中看起来要好得多。通过制作一张好的黑白照片，你确实可以将颜色看起来很糟糕的东西变成一张很棒的照片毕竟，街头摄影是关于照片中的内容，而黑白通常有助于集中注意力！）

18. 编辑时对照片进行分组

确保经常查看你的街头照片，并根据感觉对它们进行分组。将它们排列成松散的叙述。回到这些群体中，向其中添加内容，或者从其中删除内容。随着时间的推移，你会注意到想法有机地增长，你会开始受到启发去拍摄更多的镜头、不同的镜头、有趣的镜头。

“照片分组”的终极表现是一本书，你可能最终会考虑将其中一本放在一起。然而，在您走上这条路之前，请为您的办公室墙壁购买一块简单的软木板，并在其中填充 4×6 和 5×7 的图像。不断打印和替换照片以创建有凝聚力的图像墙。这很有趣，是查看进度的好方法，也非常适合发展想法和灵感。

19.探索其他摄影师的作品

这是一个非常简单的技巧，但却非常重要。

在空闲时间，查找街头摄影师的作品并研究他们的作品集。探索内容，学习技术，并思考您喜欢的风格。观看这些摄影师的拍摄视频，了解他们如何拍摄街道。去画廊展览并观看现实生活中的印刷品来训练你的眼睛。这将为您提供一系列关于下次外出拍摄时要拍摄什么的想法。

另外，不要害怕超越坦率的街头照片类型。例如，你可以考虑看静物街拍、建筑街拍或街头肖像——无论你感兴趣什么，一定要追求它，因为它只会对你的摄影有所帮助！

所有这些都是鼓舞人心且有趣的。开始收集摄影书，甚至购买几张照片挂在墙上。你身边的街头照片越多，你就会变得越好，你的想法就越多，你的灵感就越多。

如果您不确定从哪里开始，可以查看以下令人难以置信的坦率街头射击者列表：

  • 亨利·卡蒂埃·布列松
  • 加里·温诺格兰德
  • 罗伯特·弗兰克
  • 海伦·莱维特
  • 李·弗里德兰德
  • 威廉·埃格尔斯顿
  • 沃克·埃文斯
  • 森山大道
  • 马丁·帕尔
  • 埃利奥特·厄维特
  • 乔尔·迈耶罗维茨
  • 玛丽·艾伦·马克
  • 布鲁斯·戴维森
  • 索尔·莱特
  • 特伦特·帕克
  • 亚历克斯·韦伯
  • 维维安·迈尔
  • 布鲁斯·吉尔登

偷拍街头摄影：最后的话

既然你知道如何提高你的街拍街拍水平了，那就出去玩吧！

您花在拍摄上的时间越多，您的图像看起来就越好。因此，不断练习，不断发展你的技能，不断磨练你的技艺。

请记住，街头摄影最困难的部分是走出前门。这些瞬间随处可见，但您需要在场并勇敢地使用相机才能捕捉到它们。现在拿起你的装备，享受乐趣吧！

提高建筑细节摄影的 11 个技巧首先出现在Digital Photography School上。它的作者是约翰·麦金泰尔。

;

提高建筑细节摄影的 11 个技巧首先出现在Digital Photography School上。它的作者是约翰·麦金泰尔。

本文于 2024 年 4 月更新，由 John McIntire、Jaymes Dempsey 和Jeff Guyer贡献。

在进行建筑摄影时，很容易迷失在宏伟的建筑中，但细节也很重要。事实上，只要掌握一些专业知识，您就可以拍摄出与广阔的广角结构照片一样好甚至更好的建筑细节摄影。

我喜欢拍摄建筑细节，在本文中，我将解释如何拍摄自己的精彩细节照片。我提供了大量我最喜欢的技巧、技巧和技术——经过长时间的练习而形成的——重点关注两个基本的建筑摄影元素：灯光和构图。

当您读完时，您一定会迫不及待地拿起相机拍摄一些细节！

1.寻找柔和的光线来强调细节

如果天气不好，天空呈单调、无色的灰色，你就应该待在室内，对吗？不完全是！

多云的天气似乎对建筑摄影不利，但事实并非如此。您会看到，阴天提供了令人难以置信的柔和光线，在建筑照片中看起来很棒，尤其是在拍摄摄影师容易忽视的小细节的照片中。

事实上，柔和的光线实际上可以呈现出高对比度照明中丢失的所有细节，使您能够创建高度描述性的屋顶、建筑物边缘、铭文等的复杂图像。

柔和的光线也非常适合呈现色彩；看看下一张照片中绿色和黄色是如何流行的：

即使您在晴天拍摄，您仍然可以找到柔和的光线。要么等待云朵掠过太阳，要么留意阴凉处的拍照机会。虽然阴影光通常不如阴天光那么柔和可爱，但它仍然看起来很棒：

最后一点提示：如果您想拍摄清晰的建筑细节照片，您肯定需要三脚架。柔和的光线虽然美丽，但并不强烈，您将被迫降低快门速度以获得足够的景深。我不建议在这种情况下手持相机；相反，带上三脚架，使用遥控快门释放，并捕捉一些清晰的图像。

2.使用强烈的侧光

阴天光线非常适合拍摄细节丰富的图像，但如果您想要拍摄更强烈、阴暗甚至抽象的照片怎么办？

这时候侧光就派上用场了。

不，它不会展示复杂的细节，但它可以让您通过强调纹理和形状将建筑物变成美术杰作：

为了获得最佳的侧光，请在阳光明媚的早晨或下午拍摄。注意太阳的位置，然后寻找从侧面照射的物体（加或减几度！）。不要害怕阴影曝光不足或高光过曝——这种外观可以增加抽象效果——但要小心；你不想让高对比度的构图太过分。

3.寻找高光和阴影

有时，最好的建筑细节摄影较少关注建筑细节……

......以及更多关于光线落在建筑物上的方式。例如，午后的光线可以产生有趣的阴影，您可以将其变成强大的抽象主题。看看我如何在以下步骤中仅使用阴影创建合成：

这就是为什么我建议您始终密切关注太阳、它在天空中的位置以及它如何落在场景中。一旦您注意到一些有趣的阴影或高光，就靠近一些。考虑如何将它们整合到一个强大的图像中。并测试不同的相机角度和取景，直到获得您喜欢的建筑构图！

顺便说一句，为了获得最佳效果，我建议在天空晴朗且阳光强烈时出发。正午会产生大量强烈的阴影，而早晨和下午则有更柔和但同样有趣的阴影。

4.寻找更高的有利位置

探索建筑细节摄影通常从地面开始，但上面有一个全新的视角在等着您。冒险到更高的有利位置可以通过揭示您从下面可能不会注意到的细节和模式来显着改变您的镜头。

另外，如果你能站得高，你经常会遇到其他建筑元素——柱子的顶部、复杂的飞檐和华丽的门框——当直接拍摄时，它们看起来完全不同。

如果您的拍摄对象是室内空间，请寻找楼梯或阳台来提升您的视角。但请记住，安全和许可至关重要；始终确保您实际上被允许使用这些更高的位置，而不会冒对自己或建筑物造成伤害的风险。

对于户外摄影，有利位置的选择包括停车场和邻近建筑物的无障碍窗户。更现代的解决方案是使用无人机，它可以从上方提供无与伦比的视野。但如果你确实朝这个方向发展，安全合法地操作无人机、尊重隐私并在必要时获得许可至关重要。

5. 寻找架构中的模式

拍摄建筑细节时我最喜欢的一点是构图的可能性。人造结构充满了图案和形状，只要稍加努力，您就可以利用它们来创作令人难以置信的照片！

对于最强大的图像，我建议您使用长焦镜头，然后 - 当您发现有趣的图案时 - 放大以填充画面。确保仔细注意光圈和景深；虽然没有单一的最佳方法，但您应该考虑不同的选择并选择适合您愿景的设置。

对于这张建筑细节图像，我使用了窄光圈来实现深景深：

请注意，从右前方的窗口到左后方的窗口，整个图案非常清晰。

浅景深效果虽然比较非正统，但效果也很好：

6.寻找倒影

是的，世界上有风景如画的建筑，但也充满了单调和丑陋的建筑，如果你问大多数摄影师，这些建筑很少值得拍摄。

但事实上，丑陋的建筑确实提供了很多可以拍摄的地方！你只需要发挥一点创意即可。

这是我的建议：

如果你面对的是一栋单调的建筑，请环顾四周。看看是否可以在附近（最好是街对面）找到任何反光表面，例如窗户或汽车引擎盖。然后靠近表面并尝试不同的角度，试图反映丑陋的建筑。我还建议测试不同的焦点；通过聚焦于反射表面本身，您将获得一张照片，但通过聚焦于反射的建筑物，您将获得完全不同的结果。

幸运的是，您会发现一个有趣的作品，您会找到正确的重点点，并设法捕获一张令人惊叹的照片。即使是无聊的建筑物，也具有凉爽的反射效果！

7.照片灯具

建筑细节摄影不仅与建筑物有关。

您会看到，外部细节也为出色的主题提供了，我绝对喜欢拍摄的物品之一是谦虚的灯具：

没有人注意灯具，但它们经常提供美丽的色彩，强大的形状，引人注目的线条，并且在夜间拍摄时 - 可爱的金色光芒。

顺便说一句，不要只是坚持灯具。一旦您检查了建筑物上的所有灯，请搜索其他有趣的物品，例如标志，安全摄像头，门把手和门。

专家提示：为了捕获固定装置的惊人镜头，您需要使用远摄镜头；许多固定装置位于地面太远，无法以宽阔的焦距强调。而且，如果您打算捕获特别小的主题（例如门把手上的复杂雕刻），请尝试使用宏观镜头。

8.不要忘记那个三脚架！

许多建筑摄影师用三脚架捕捉了他们的广角图像，但是您知道在拍摄细节时与三脚架一起工作会带来很大的不同吗？三脚架可以稳定您的相机，从而可以降低快门速度而不会出现模糊的风险，这对于实现具有深度景深的锋利图像至关重要。

另外，使用三脚架会鼓励一种周到的构图方法。它邀请您抽出时间，考虑框架并以不同的角度和观点进行实验。这个故意的过程通常会导致更引人注目的图像，因此，如果您尚未尝试使用三脚架拍摄建筑细节，我鼓励您拍摄它。

一个警告：请注意周围的环境。三脚架在繁忙的内部或拥挤的外观中可能是令人震惊的，并且一些场所限制了（或禁止）使用。始终询问到达后的三脚架政策，以免给您带来任何不便或破坏！

9.当心关键陷阱

在您出发之前，请注意建筑细节摄影的一些常见陷阱。

即使您没有拍摄整个建筑物，您仍然必须小心地将相机倾斜太远并造成失真。当您向后倾斜以通过相机抬头看建筑物时，传感器的底部比传感器的顶部更靠近建筑物，从而产生了建筑物顶部看起来比底部狭窄的图像。虽然您在拍摄细节时不会经常遇到此问题，但您仍然需要意识到它。

另外，请注意窗户和玻璃门中的反射。有时，将角度稍微转移，这样您就不会直接以90度角向玻璃拍摄，可以纠正问题（并将自己的反射从照片中远离）。

10.不要忘记雕像！

建筑摄影师很少关注雕像，但这些是许多建筑物和古迹的关键部分。例如，布拉格的查尔斯桥（Charles Bridge）有30个大型详细雕像，这些雕像要拍照。

所以不要跳过雕像摄影！另外，这很有趣，尤其是当您开始尝试不同的方法和技术时。

您可以低下以将雕像击倒天空，您可以找到有利的点并击落，也可以用雕像的水平射击。确保您也要仔细注意照明； Sidelight会强调纹理，多云的光将带来细节，背光会产生美丽的耀斑和/或剪影效果。

最后，请确保改变焦距。您可以缩小以全部捕获雕像，但是您也可以缩小并专注于头部，边缘，手势和其他细节：

11.转换为黑白

建筑细节镜头通常基于强大的构图。

通过将颜色从镜头中剥离，您可以在让分散注意力的元素退缩的同时强调构图。

这就是为什么我强烈建议您将建筑细节照片转换为黑白的原因。 （如果您的构图充满纹理或强大的图案，此举往往可以很好地工作。）

当然，并非所有细节的镜头看起来都很好，这是可以的。您可以在Lightroom或Photoshop中应用此转换，然后，如果您不喜欢结果，则只需取消调整即可。

但是以我的经验，单色建筑照片通常很棒！

建筑细节摄影技巧：最后一句话

现在您已经完成了这篇文章，您知道如何使用Light。您知道如何创建美丽的作品。而且您知道如何发现有趣的主题。

换句话说，您准备捕捉一些令人惊叹的建筑细节摄影！

所以用相机出去。使用这些技巧。并拍好照片！

帖子如何做钢羊毛摄影：基本指南首先出现在数字摄影学校上。它是由安德鲁·吉布森（Andrew S. Gibson）撰写的。

帖子如何做钢羊毛摄影：基本指南首先出现在数字摄影学校上。它是由安德鲁·吉布森（Andrew S. Gibson）撰写的。

本文于2024年4月更新了Simon Ringsmuth和Andrew S. Gibson的贡献。

有时，您可以找到拍摄令人惊叹的照片而无需花费很多钱的方法，而其中最好的例子之一就是一种称为火旋转的技术，有时也称为钢羊毛摄影。

捕获惊人的钢羊毛照片通常只涉及几个基本物品 - 在任何五金店和杂货市场上都可以买到一些创造力。一旦理解了简单的过程，您就可以创建令人叹为观止的图像，甚至超凡脱俗的图像。从初学者到专业人士，愿意在太阳下来的任何人都可以访问此技术。结果始终是火与运动的独特融合，可以将任何空间从字面上转变为戏剧性美景。

在本文中，我分享了我对惊人的钢羊毛图像的方法以及大量的示例照片，因此您知道会发生什么。

让我们开始吧！

什么是钢羊毛摄影？

钢羊毛摄影的核心是光，运动和创造力的令人兴奋的融合。它从像钢羊毛一样平凡的东西开始 - 您可能会在厨房或车间中找到那种。当这种羊毛被照亮并迅速旋转时，它将成为可以使用相机捕获的发光火花的来源。

成功捕获此显示的关键是在您的相机设置中。长时间的曝光（通常为10秒或更长时间）可确保您的相机记录火花，因为在黑暗的背景上亮着明亮的步道。

钢羊毛摄影的结果令人叹为观止。但是，正如我在下一节中讨论的那样，安全至关重要。在远离任何易燃的安全区域中进行此操作，并准备好水或灭火器。穿防护服是个好主意。安全完成后，钢羊毛摄影会产生令人叹为观止的图像，从而捕捉黑暗中光的动态运动。

钢羊毛摄影安全警告（请遵守！）

在详细介绍创建这样的图像所需的内容之前，我需要清楚地表明，火旋转是危险的，不仅对您自己，而且对您周围的区域甚至相机设备都是危险的。请遵循以下安全预防措施：

  • 注意只有在您有足够的开放空间的地方，而周围的任何东西都不会着火。
  • 确保穿厚厚的衣服，例如全长的裤子，闭合鞋，一件长袖衬衫以及遮住眼睛（眼镜或安全护目镜）和头发的东西。
  • 切勿在草地或房屋，干木或刷子附近或任何可能着火的东西附近这样做。
  • 另外，请确保在相机和火花之间保持足够的距离，因为它们的飞行比您想象的要远！

您在本文中看到的图像都是在夜间在一个荒芜的海滩上拍摄的，在那里没有其他东西可以开始燃烧，我的相机离主题足够远，以避免任何任意的飞行火花或闷烧的余烬。

如何拍摄钢羊毛：您需要什么

您可能已经有一些旋转照片所需的物品，但是如果没有，您只需几美元就可以轻松找到所需的一切。您可以添加其他内容，例如多个链条和搅拌，以创建不同的效果和样式，但是对于基本的火旋转拍摄，您可以从以下小饰品开始：

  • 几块细钢羊毛（厚实的东西都可以，但是更好的钢羊毛更好：0-0000级）
  • 一条小链，长度大约半米（1.5'）
  • 烘烤通常使用的电线
  • 一个小扣子或登山扣，将链条固定在搅拌器上
  • 点燃火上的钢羊毛的东西（烟火打火机，打火机等）

拍摄所需的其他项目包括：

  • 相机的三脚架
  • 广角镜头（我以50mm的速度拍摄了顶部图片，但我会更喜欢更宽的东西，例如35mm）
  • 手电筒，因此您可以在设置相机并计划拍摄时看到
  • 一个愿意持有链条上的旋风对象的朋友

如何为开火的照片做准备

一旦拥有所有需要的东西，准备照片就相当简单。将一团钢羊毛塞进搅拌中（绒毛稍微弄些，以便它有一些空气），将搅拌器连接到链条上，然后将其固定。细钢羊毛更好（我将00级用于这些图像），因为它会更容易燃烧，并在拍摄过程中发送更多的火花。

基本想法涉及照明钢羊毛，这会导致其闷烧，然后在空中旋转，这会导致火花向各个方向射出。

虽然钢羊毛不会像纸一样燃烧，但在空中旋转会导致火花飞来飞去。通过在相机上使用长时间的曝光，您可以捕获令人难以置信的动态图像，这与您在独立日庆祝活动中展示时可能看到的东西不同。

开火方法

链条，搅拌和钢羊毛准备好后，您需要找到一个位置并决定如何构架镜头，这就是为什么让朋友帮助您的原因。您可以自己拍摄钢羊毛照片，但这确实有助于指导其他正在旋转的人，以便您可以将所有内容完全定位在镜头中。

它有助于在沙子或污垢中绘制一些线条，以便您的助手精确地知道在哪里站立，并且根据其黑暗的不同，您可能需要使用手电筒来帮助使所有物体恰到好处。

其余过程非常简单，但是要获得想要的镜头可能会需要大量的反复试验。将您的相机和三脚架放在地面上，距离朋友几米，并让他们在身体上发光手电筒，以便您可以锁定焦点（要么使用自动对焦锁定，然后将其切换为手动 - 或尝试Back按钮Focus） 。

由于您想要非常宽的景深，因此应该避免大量孔径，并且您不必担心会收集足够的光线，因为即使有小孔，火花也会很明亮。使用20或30秒的长时间曝光时间，而低ISO为100或200。

当您准备好射击时，请让您的朋友将打火机放在钢羊毛下，直到它开始发光。那是您的提示按下快门按钮，然后在您的朋友旋转链条和火花开始飞行的同时站起来。一个窍门是使用相机的2秒自我接手，这样您的朋友有一些时间在实际曝光开始之前点燃钢羊毛。

钢羊毛摄影的想法和例子

一旦您掌握了基础知识，其余的就是找到一种有效的技术，以获取想要的照片。您可以尝试许多变体来获取不同的照片，例如：

  • 站在适当的位置，绕链子旋转
  • 站在适当的位置，旋转两个连锁店，每侧一个
  • 在旋转链条时穿过框架以创建巨大的发光管
  • 镜头中有多个人旋转多个连锁店
  • 在岩石或其他背景元素上闪烁摄像机外闪光灯，以增加镜头的深度

通过稍作练习，您可以获得一些惊人的结果，并且以RAW拍摄总是很好，以便您可以调整颜色，并在稍后稍后从阴影中获取一些细节。如果您在网上搜索“燃式旋转照片”（或钢羊毛旋转），您将使用此基本技术的各种变体找到数千张图像。我意识到这句话有些陈词滥调，但是可能性确实是无尽的。

如果您在还剩下一点光线时拍摄，天空将具有很好的深蓝色。有些人在晚上使用这种技术，并将其与绘画与光线（使用手电筒或便携式闪光灯）结合起来，以构建图像或捕获星形步道。

钢羊毛摄影：最后一句话

好吧，你已经有了：

捕获美丽的钢羊毛照片的简单，逐步的过程。

如您所见，获得稳定的结果并不一定要困难，但确实需要一定的毅力和实验！

最终，火旋转是另一种用光的绘画形式，因为燃烧的钢羊毛的光以一种新有趣的方式照亮了景观。

玩得开心！

两极分化过滤器是景观摄影师的重要工具，但这是事实：

有时，使用偏光剂是一个坏主意。

我说了！是的，在某些圈子中不使用两极分化过滤器进行景观拍摄可以被视为牺牲性，实际上，我本人已经为这位简单但功能强大的摄影师工具的重要性写下了Ad Ad Adeam 。

但是，今天我将有选择地与自己矛盾。因为虽然在大多数户外摄影情况下，圆形两极过滤器可以大大改善您的照片，但有时候将那件玻璃脱离镜头实际上可以给出更好的效果。

在下面，我列出了所有时间，我相信最好避免使用偏光滤镜，并包括示例照片，以帮助您更好地了解偏振器在这些特定情况下如何对您的图像产生负面影响。

因此，如果您准备了解所有有关时间的了解，那么您应该将偏振器收拾好，让我们开始吧！

圆形偏振器会做什么？

偏振器在进入镜头之前会降低反射光。它并不能完全消除所有反射光；取而代之的是，它靶向极化光，这是在光源从某些材料中弹出时会产生的。

请注意，圆形极化器设计为灵活性。这些过滤器包括两块玻璃，通过旋转前元元素，您可以参与或脱离偏光效果。

现在，偏振器在拍摄反射表面（例如水，玻璃，闪亮的汽车和湿岩石）时很有用。通过将偏振器放在镜头上，您可以减少反射，以突出下面的颜色和细节。景观摄影师不断使用极化器来射击秋天的叶子（减少对蜡状叶子表面的反射）和瀑布（以减少对湿岩石的反射），而City -Scape和产品摄影师有时喜欢依靠这些过滤器来避免对汽车和建筑物的极端反思。

在大多数情况下，您想控制这些反射性表面，并减少反射光的眩光，以使下面的颜色和细节闪耀。但是，如果您喜欢某些表面上的超级湿外观和眩光怎么办？如果您认为它可以增强照片怎么办？

在这种情况下，您需要将圆形偏振器留在相机袋中。让我给你一些例子，我觉得不使用偏振器实际上是为了更好的图像。

1.当反射光带有颜色时

For the image above, I decided to remove my polarizer, and here's why:

The reflected light on the wet rocks in the foreground had a distinct red color, which I loved. The rocks were a beautiful deep red that matched the water and the bright sky, and by working without a polarizer, I was able to maintain that harmony throughout the image.

Using a polarizer would have reduced the beautiful red reflected light, resulting in a less dramatic image.

So if you're faced with a scenario where you appreciate the color of the reflected light, don't be afraid to take that polarizer off. Reflections can add beautiful color to an image, and that's not something you want to miss out on!

2. When you want that super wet look

Since wet elements tend to produce contrast and desaturate colors, photographers generally use circular polarizers when faced with waterfalls, seascapes, etc. But wet objects can look good in certain situations – sometimes, the wet reflections create pops of brightness that enhance the resulting image.

For instance, look at the long-exposure image above. If you check out the wet rocks, especially those in the bottom left-hand corner and the wall jutting out in the midground, you'll notice some bright highlights. A polarizer would reduce contrast in these areas to help the real color of the rocks shine through – but I quite liked the way the highlights caused a soft glare from reflected sunlight.

So even though the highlights didn't really have any dramatic color, I still felt that the wet look made for a better image, so I opted not to use the polarizer.

3. When photographing in very low light or in totally shaded areas

When the sun has gone down and it's starting to get dark, there's little point in using a polarizer. Polarizers only cut down on reflected light, and when the light is dim, reflections are pretty subtle.

Plus, using a polarizer in low light will force you to use a longer shutter speed; circular polarizers block out a couple of stops of light, which can make a big difference when you're working in dim conditions.

The shot above features a waterfall at Silver Falls State Park. It was a long exposure in very dim light, taken inside a canyon that had no direct sunlight at the time. The only wet surfaces that could cause glare were the leaves in the foreground, and the light was so dim that there was no glare at all.

Therefore, I opted to leave my polarizer off my lens.

4. When you're shooting at night

If you read the last section carefully, you probably know what I'm going to say here.

Polarizers only help when dealing with reflected light, and when you're photographing at night, there won't be a whole lot of reflected light to handle.

Additionally, when you're photographing at night , you want to get as much light as possible into your lens. A polarizer is going to reduce the amount of light and force you to use a longer shutter speed or a higher ISO setting .

So if you're shooting in the dark, do yourself a favor and remove the polarizer.

When capturing the full moon shot above, the polarizer would only have served to slow down my shutter speed, so I kept it stowed away in my bag.

5. When you want reflections in water

Sometimes, you come across a scene with reflections in the water, and they look beautiful . One option is to ditch your polarizer and shoot with a bare lens.

But let's say you like the look of your image with the polarizer on. Your colors are nicely saturated and all of the glare has been reduced from the surfaces, but you're annoyed to see that the lovely reflections in the water have either vanished or diminished.

你做什么工作？

The simple answer is to take two shots – one with the polarizer engaged and another without the polarizer. Then you can blend the two exposures in Photoshop and take the best elements from each.

For the shot above, I really enjoyed the look of the reflected waterfall in the pool, so I took two shots with different polarizer settings and then combined them.

6. When you want to shoot rainbows

I'm sure I'll be corrected by our more well-educated readers, but from a polarizer's standpoint, a rainbow is reflected light.

Regardless, if your polarizer is engaged, the rainbow will perform a disappearing act in your photo.

Disengage or remove the polarizer and – presto! – the rainbow will be back in your photograph.

In other words, if you want to photograph a rainbow successfully, where all the colors are as vivid as possible, take that polarizer off.

Note: If you want to reduce reflections in other parts of the shot, you can always use the technique I mentioned above, where you capture two shots – one polarized and one unpolarized – and blend the files together.

But still don't forget your polarizer!

As I mentioned at the start of this article, a polarizer is a key landscape photography tool.

In fact, if I leave the house and forget my polarizers, I'll actually turn around and drive home; they're that important.

At the same time, I urge you to learn when conditions call for the removal of your polarizer, and to confidently unscrew that polarizer when the time is right.

And I hope this article helps you identify those golden moments so that you can get the best possible shots!

(Of course, if you're unsure whether to shoot with or without a polarizer in a specific scenario, you can always capture multiple shots, then decide which one you prefer when you're back at home.)

On the afternoon of April 8th, 2024, a total solar eclipse will be visible for a huge swathe of mainland North America. The post How to Photograph a Solar Eclipse (An Essential Guide) appeared first on Digital Photography School . It was authored by Simon Ringsmuth .

;

The post How to Photograph a Solar Eclipse (An Essential Guide) appeared first on Digital Photography School . It was authored by Simon Ringsmuth .

On the afternoon of April 8th, 2024, a total solar eclipse will be visible for a huge swathe of mainland North America. And while total solar eclipses aren't an entirely uncommon phenomenon, it is highly irregular for one to be seen by such a large portion of the country, and it won't happen again anytime soon.

As a result, anyone who wants to get some good photographs of the upcoming event will need to spend time preparing, getting some essential gear, or even traveling to the USA if you live in another country.

Fortunately, you don't need to spend thousands of dollars to get a good shot of the eclipse. This guide is designed to give you a good idea of what you will need without breaking the bank.

什么是日食？

To understand a bit about photographing a solar eclipse, it's important to know just what it is you will be looking at when the event finally occurs.

The moon orbits the earth once every 28 days, but the plane of the moon's orbit is not quite even with the plane of the earth's orbit around the sun. Because of this disparity, the moon does not usually block out our view of the sun. However, every so often, the moon passes between the earth and the sun, blocking out the sunlight. This is known as a solar eclipse . You can also witness lunar eclipses, where the Earth passes between the sun and the moon – but solar eclipses are rarer and, in my opinion, more spectacular to watch.

The fun part happens when you are lucky enough to be in the path of totality , which is where you will experience a complete blackout of the sun during the middle of the day. Keep reading to find out what gear you will need to photograph the eclipse and how to locate the path of totality so you know where to be on this eventful day.

How can I view a solar eclipse?

The most important thing to remember when viewing the April 8th eclipse, or any solar eclipse, is that you do not want to look directly at it unless the moon is completely covering the sun.

I must make this abundantly clear: do not look at the solar eclipse with your naked eyes!

Even if most of the sun is covered up by the moon, the light streaming out will be much too bright for your eyes to handle. NASA's website has more detailed information on eclipse safety , but suffice it to say that, if you want to watch the eclipse unfold in real-time, you will need something to protect your eyes like these solar eclipse glasses or a strong piece of welding glass 。 Sunglasses are far too weak to be effective (and squinting definitely won't work, either!

Protect your eyes properly. They're the only ones you've got.

How do I take pictures of the eclipse?

Here's where things get a little tricky. You will probably need to spend a bit of money, though hopefully not as much as you think. If you want to get the kind of close-up images you've already seen in this article, you will need the following camera gear:

  • A zoom lens, preferably one that has a focal length of at least 400mm.
  • A solar filter to protect your lens and camera.
  • Solar glasses so you can watch the eclipse unfold as it happens.
  • A tripod to hold your camera steady.
  • A place to view the eclipse free of obstructions.

Here's a bit more information about each piece of eclipse photography gear so you can make sure to get the best photos possible:

Lens and camera recommendations for eclipse photography

Most consumer-level telephoto zooms do a good job covering a variety of focal lengths. But these lenses rarely go past 200mm, and shooting at 200mm isn't going to capture the solar eclipse with as much resolution and detail as you may want.

That's where a longer lens – such as the Tamron 150-600mm or the Sigma 150-600mm comes in handy. It will allow you to get a much closer view and to take the kind of close-up eclipse pictures you see on blogs and magazine covers. The downside is that these longer lenses are quite expensive.

Fortunately, there are several places online where you can rent lenses for a few days at a time, which I highly recommend. BorrowLenses , Lensrentals , and LensProToGo are popular sites that all carry a similar lineup of lenses, but it's also a good idea to check with your local brick-and-mortar camera shop. Many of these stores will let you rent lenses for a very short period of time, which is good (since you only need one day to photograph the eclipse).

If you don't want to spend extra money on a super-telephoto lens, one alternative is to buy or rent a teleconverter that will increase the focal length of your existing lenses. A 2x teleconverter – which will turn a 200mm lens into a 400mm lens – can be rented for about $35 (depending on your location).

While the resulting images won't be quite as sharp as if you were using a dedicated zoom lens, a teleconverter should be more than adequate to give you enough reach to photograph the eclipse with a lens you already own.

(Note: Some point-and-shoot cameras have impressive zoom lenses, but I would advise against using these for a solar eclipse. Unfortunately, there's just not a good way to attach a solar filter to a point-and-shoot camera, which I describe in the next section.)

Finally, it's worth noting that crop-sensor cameras are ideally suited for this type of event because they will give you more reach out of your lenses. A 200mm lens on a Nikon crop-sensor camera effectively becomes a 300mm lens, and the same holds true for Canon. Cameras with four-thirds sensors are even better; they have a 2x crop factor, so shooting with a 200mm lens on an Olympus MFT model is like using a 400mm lens on a standard full-frame mirrorless camera or DSLR.

Bottom line: For shooting the eclipse, if you have access to both crop-sensor and full-frame cameras, you will be better off relying on the crop.

A solar filter

You shouldn't look directly at the sun during an eclipse without proper protective equipment for your eyes, and the same is true for your camera. If you are lucky enough to be in the path of totality, you can look at, and take pictures of, the eclipse without needing any special gear – but only during the few minutes when the sun is completely covered by the moon.

However, if you are anywhere except the line of the complete blackout, or you want to take pictures of the eclipse as it begins and ends, you will need certain equipment to keep your camera safe.

A special solar filter that attaches to the end of your lens is a great way to protect against damage to your camera. Not to be confused with standard neutral density filters – which are not anywhere near strong enough for this type of situation – solar filters are specifically designed to photograph eclipses and other solar events.

Make sure to find a solar filter that screws on, or fits over, the end of the lens you plan to use for eclipse photography. Do not use a solar filter that goes between your camera and lens.

If it's a screw-on filter, it needs to fit your lens perfectly, so double-check that the thread size of the filter you get matches the thread size of your lens. (The lens thread size is generally displayed on the front of the lens, and you can also find it written on your lens cap and lens hood).

太阳能眼镜

Solar glasses function much in the same way that a solar filter does, but they're designed to protect your eyes instead of your camera. They are not expensive and look like the old style of 3D glasses you might have used in a movie theater decades ago, except these block out virtually all light except what comes from extraordinarily bright objects (like the sun).

While wearing solar glasses won't help you take better photos of a solar eclipse, it's good to wear them as the eclipse waxes and wanes so you can see it with your own eyes instead of through your camera's viewfinder.

A tripod

Unless you have very steady hands or an impressive image stabilization system on your camera, a tripod is essential for shooting an eclipse. While you don't need anything fancy or expensive, it will help to have a larger one that can keep your camera and lens rock-steady. That's why I would recommend against those small, mount-anywhere tripods that you can find rather cheaply online.

If you are using a zoom lens with a built-in tripod mount, make sure to attach your tripod to the lens instead of the camera. Otherwise, you will put a great deal of stress on the camera mount, which can lead to damage.

Finally, any time you use a tripod, make sure you disable your lens's image stabilization system. If you leave IS technology active, it can backfire on you and actually make your images more blurry when your camera setup is completely free of camera shake (such as when mounted on a tripod).

A place to view the eclipse

If you have all your gear ready, solar glasses on your face, and your friends and family gathered to witness this historic event, it could all be for naught if you don't put yourself in the proper location. The best spot to view any solar eclipse is in a location along the path of totality – the geographic line where you will see an entire blackout of the sun for up to a few minutes. Places not aligned with the path of totality will still see part of the eclipse, but the effect will not be nearly as pronounced.

Many towns and cities located on or near the path of totality plan community events to promote the eclipse, and they get a huge influx of tourists in the days surrounding the eclipse. So if you know that an eclipse will soon be coming to your area, book your accommodations in advance!

Try to find a park, field, or another open area free of obstructions so that you can have a clear view of the eclipse. Of course, weather plays a big role, too, and it's entirely possible that your best-laid plans will result in rain or even just a lot of clouds. If you desperately want to see an eclipse, pay attention to the weather forecast, and consider traveling to an area that tends to get many days of sunlight.

How to photograph a solar eclipse: shooting techniques

Finally, it's important to keep a few essentials in mind so you can actually get the kind of pictures you are hoping for when the eclipse happens. Here are some tips that'll be the difference between a blurry, almost-had-it shot and a brilliant glowing halo that you'll be proud to print and hang on the wall:

  • Use a fast shutter speed. This is not about stopping the vibration of your camera, which is what a tripod is for; it's about freezing the motion of the moon as it travels across the sun. A 1/125s shutter speed will be more than adequate, and going faster than that won't really give you much of an advantage. Once again, make sure you have a solar filter attached to your lens, or you will damage your camera. Get a pair of solar glasses for your eyes, too!
  • Use a small aperture. Every lens is different, but in general an aperture of f/8 or f/11 will give you a sharp image without much diffraction or chromatic aberration. If you go much larger than that (ie, f/4 or f/2.8), you risk capturing images that aren't as sharp as they could be. If you go much smaller than that (ie f/16 or f/22), you'll likely end up with blur due to diffraction.
  • Shoot in RAW , not JPEG, and correct your white balance afterward in Lightroom, Photoshop, or another similar program.
  • Use a two-second delay timer (if you're shooting with a tripod) so you don't get any vibration from your finger pressing the shutter.
  • Use Live View and manual mode to ensure perfect focus . Alternatively, you can use autofocus, but check your pictures on the LCD screen right away to make sure they are properly in focus.然而：
  • Don't spend all your time chimping , which is where you look at the LCD screen on the back of your camera after you take photos. You will only have a few minutes at most to take pictures of the total eclipse, and you will have plenty of time to admire them after it's all done.

How to photograph a solar eclipse: final words

Hopefully, you now feel prepared to effectively – and safely! – photograph any solar eclipses in your area. Just make sure to properly protect your eyes and your camera, bring the right gear, and follow the shooting techniques I recommend.

If you want to know more, PBS has a fantastic short video about the 2017 eclipse, and you can find all sorts of information by searching online including NASA's page dedicated to upcoming eclipses.

Do you have any other tips for getting photos of the upcoming eclipse? Please leave your thoughts in the comments below, and be sure to revisit this article after any eclipse to share your photos!

;

The post 12 Tips for Beautiful Spring Landscape Photography appeared first on Digital Photography School . It was authored by Simon Ringsmuth .

One of the most rewarding types of photography for beginners, hobbyists, and even seasoned professionals is spring landscape photography. As you see flowers blooming, trees budding, grass growing, and animals out and about after a long winter, there's a sense of incredible vitality, and capturing it all on camera is a lot of fun.

One of the best things about spring landscape photography is that you don't need expensive, high-end gear to get great shots. A basic DSLR or mirrorless camera with a kit lens can work great, and even a mobile phone will often yield outstanding results. (Modern phones often use built-in HDR processing , which raises shadow detail without overexposing highlights and makes spring colors look particularly vibrant.) Of course, as with everything photography-related, you can always spend more money if you want, but I have seen wall-sized landscape prints that were taken with the cheapest mobile phones, and they looked fantastic .

Creating top-notch spring landscapes generally has less to do with gear but instead comes down to other, more creative elements: understanding light, keeping an eye on composition, and being at the right place at the right time. The best course of action is to simply get out and shoot; don't let your camera collect dust on the shelf. The more you practice, even if you only use a mobile phone, the more you'll hone your craft and capture great spring landscape pictures!

That said, photographing the landscape – even when presented with the beauty of spring! – can be very challenging. These tips will help you maximize your enjoyment while minimizing your frustration – and with a little practice, you'll be capturing photos that you'll be proud to share, show off, and even print and hang on your wall.

让我们开始吧！

1. Look for signs of life

Spring is all about rebirth, renewal, and starting over, which is part of what makes this type of photography so much fun. I would even go so far as to say it's therapeutic; in other words, getting out in nature as the weather warms and the days lengthen is not only good for your pictures, but it's also good for your soul. If you can find a way to capture that newness and vitality with your camera, it can dramatically elevate your images.

You can find these signs of life and renewal all around you, even in your own backyard or while walking through a local park. Bugs, baby birds, and even buds on trees will all help showcase the magic of spring, and with your camera by your side, all you have to do is keep a keen eye open and be ready with your finger on the shutter. It might require a bit of patience, but with some care and attention, you can get great landscape shots that showcase springtime in unique and exciting ways.

2. Create a sense of scale

What's one of the most impactful things you can do to elevate your spring landscape images? Offer your viewers a sense of size and scale.

This isn't as easy as it sounds, though. If you've ever scrolled through your photo library and had the sinking feeling that your beautiful pictures of sweeping vistas just don't look very impressive, know that you are not alone. It's not easy to create a sense of scale and help your viewers experience the scene as you did, but there is one simple trick you can try that'll help enormously.

To help create a sense of scale in your spring landscape photography shots, include something in the frame that serves as a reference point for your viewers. Majestic mountains , sweeping skies, and expansive prairies just don't carry the same weight in pictures as they do in person – unless you can give your viewers some context that helps them understand the scale of what you're capturing.

The best way to provide this sense of context is to include objects that are familiar to a broad audience. Vehicles, buildings, animals, people, and even road signs or abandoned farm equipment are all things that'll help your viewers comprehend the sheer size of the scene you are photographing.

For example, the image of mountains and sky displayed above only works because of the bridge in the center. Without it, people who see the picture would have a difficult time understanding just how large the mountains, trees, and other elements of the landscape composition truly are. But because most people know roughly how big a bridge is, its relatively small size within the frame is a way of illustrating just how massive the rest of the spring nature scene really is.

3. Capture water flowing with a slow shutter speed

Spring is a great time to take photos of water in motion. Rivers, streams, and waterfalls are excellent subjects. However, despite what you might think, a slower shutter can actually produce much better results than a fast shutter. Slowing down your shutter speed turns rushing rapids into silky-smooth works of art that you might see on the cover of nature magazines or adorning the walls of a corporate lobby. Fortunately, it's easy to get these types of pictures; all it takes is a few basic exposure adjustments.

The trickiest part about using a slow shutter with spring landscape photos is finding ways to reduce the amount of incoming light, especially on sunny days. One way is to stop down the aperture of your lens as far as it will go and set your ISO to 100, but even then you might end up with a shutter speed that is too fast to create beautiful motion trails. If that's the case, try returning to the spot on a cloudy day, early in the morning, or late in the evening just as the sun is setting to limit the light.

You can also purchase an inexpensive neutral density filter that will screw onto the front of your lens and block out the light so you can use a slower shutter speed even in bright light. Of course, make sure you work with a good tripod , which is a necessity anytime you use a slow shutter.

4. Take the road less traveled

This might seem obvious to seasoned photographers, but for people who are new to spring landscape photography, it's a tip worth sharing: seek out photo opportunities where you might least expect to find them. Try simple things like going for a walk in a new neighborhood, leaving early for work and traveling on surface streets instead of interstates and highways, or visiting a park, botanic garden, or college campus that you might have seen on a map but never actually photographed.

If you're planning a road trip, give yourself a few extra hours to seek out dirt roads and two-lane highways en route to your destination. Have your camera handy and be ready to pull over and take some pictures! Even if you aren't sure you'll get any good results, it's better to try than to wonder days or weeks later about the shots that could have been. Many of my favorite spring nature photographs have been taken in these conditions, and you get the added benefit of finding new places to explore that may have been right under your nose.

5. Plan ahead

A little serendipity goes a long way, but the more you practice the art of photography, the more you'll realize that your best shots almost always involve some degree of planning. While you can certainly get stunning images by accidentally being in the right place at the right time, you will get the most consistent results if you do some homework in advance. Take note of things like sunrise and sunset times, the direction of the light, and even the weather forecast. Then make sure you have the gear you need to get the photos you want!

The picture displayed above – which features a spring sunset – was not the result of random chance. It took careful planning and a great deal of experience, not to mention several failed attempts before I was able to nail the shot. I had to learn what worked and what didn't work, and I had to understand how to use my camera to get the photo just right. Even the sunburst rays were no accident! I only had a couple of minutes to get the photo, but I'm incredibly proud of the result. With a bit of planning and preparation, you can get similar shots.

6. Put flowers in the foreground

This technique may not get you the most original images, but it works almost every time. Simply include a few flowers in the foreground, which will give your viewers something colorful to focus on while adding a sense of scope and scale.

To get the best results, open your lens aperture as wide as it can go, get low to the ground so you are looking out at the landscape, focus on the flower, and take the shot. It helps if the sun is behind you so your flowers are evenly lit, though it's also possible to get some creative and interesting results with a bit of backlighting .

While you can't control every variable every time, it can help to photograph on an overcast day so the sky isn't blown out. Also, look for compositional elements that can help frame your subject while still conveying a sense of scale. In the image above, which I shot one rainy afternoon in April, I carefully positioned my camera so that a large tree was directly behind the dandelion so the bright white would stand out even more.

7. Maintain a harmonious color palette

In landscape photography, you often don't have a whole lot of control over the colors in your image – after all, the landscape is the landscape, right? But it's important to remember that simple compositions tend to be better than more complex compositions, and when you're composing, color is a key element!

In other words, you can often create better spring landscape images by paying careful attention to the colors in your shots, and by doing your best to keep things simple. You generally don't want to incorporate too many colors in a single frame, and the colors you do include should work together well.

For instance, you can look for scenes that have two or three similar colors, such as red, brown, and green, like this shot here:

You can also seek out more monochromatic springtime scenes that are entirely green, or you can look for scenes that allow you to pair beautiful green foliage with a deep blue sky.

Basically, if you're struggling to make an image work, consider the possibility that the colors may be the culprit. And though you can't control the colors directly, you can always adjust your camera's angle, zoom in, or simply photograph a different scene so that you capture an image with a more harmonious color palette!

8. Wake up early

One of my favorite techniques for great spring landscape photos has more to do with your alarm clock than your camera; simply scope out a good spot during the day, then return to capture the scene as the sunrises. You'll be amazed at the results you can achieve!

A brief warning: If you've never taken pictures like this, you'll be shocked at how little time you have between the first glint of sun on the horizon and full-on daylight. However, if you're prepared and ready to go, you can get unique photos that are literally impossible to capture at any other time of day.

9. Use a tripod

When taking pictures of people, animals, or everyday life, a tripod is not all that useful. However, for spring landscape photography, it's practically a requirement. When working with a tripod, you have much greater flexibility and freedom because it lets you use nearly any aperture and shutter speed combination while keeping your ISO low. Additionally, smaller apertures almost always get sharper images, which often requires a slower shutter speed – which is almost impossible without a tripod.

The nice thing about this technique is that it doesn't have to be expensive. Of course, you can spend lots of money on a nice travel tripod , but there are plenty of cheaper models – and even models for mobile phones – that work great, too. A simple tripod from your local department store will be enough to tackle most scenarios, and it'll help you evaluate whether you might wish to eventually upgrade to something more sturdy.

10. Photograph when the sky is right

When spring rolls around, it's easy to get so excited about photographing the landscape that you forget to consider the sky. But if you want the sky to contribute to your landscape photos – which is important, especially when shooting with a wide-angle lens! – you need it to look its best.

A heavily overcast sky with no definition tends to make for less-than-stellar landscape shots, whereas a sky that's filled with interesting clouds, especially at sunrise and sunset, will do a great job of complementing the landscape below it. The point isn't to only photograph when you have cotton-candy clouds, but simply to think about the different types of cloud cover, and how they will – or won't – work with your subject.

On days with dramatic skies, you might want to focus on capturing wider scenes that emphasize the grandeur of the landscape underneath the breathtaking sky, as I did for the image displayed above. And on days when the sky is relatively flat, try focusing on creating intimate spring landscape images that highlight specific features – trees, flowers, wildlife – and rely less on the sky.合理？

11. Shoot in RAW

If you're an experienced shooter, you probably already know this one, but beginners might not realize the incredible benefits of shooting in RAW . The enormous amount of data stored in RAW files gives you the flexibility to brighten shadows, salvage color from brightly lit skies, and make images go from average to awesome. All DSLR and mirrorless cameras can shoot in RAW and so can some mobile phones, so if you've never tried it before, go ahead and give it a whirl. You might be amazed at what you have been missing out on!

Check out this first image, which is how the unprocessed RAW file looked:

Then check out this next shot, which displays the file after some processing:

RAW is great, but be aware that you might need to bring extra memory cards or sign up for cloud storage if you constantly shoot in RAW. RAW files are much larger than JPEGs (though you can use programs like Rawsie to essentially get the best of both worlds). While I don't recommend RAW for every occasion – when capturing casual snapshots of friends and family, it can be overkill – but I do strongly encourage you to use the format for spring nature photography.

12. Frame the scene with foliage

As the trees start to leaf out in spring, you have the opportunity to use a handy composition trick – where you create depth and interest by framing your main subject with lush green foliage in the foreground.

The idea is to find an interesting main subject – such as a hill or a stand of trees in the distance – and then adjust your position until you have some leaf-filled branches in the foreground. Here, the foreground branches should act as a frame; in other words, they shouldn't distract the viewer from the main subject, but they should help push the eye toward its resting point elsewhere in the shot.

When done well, the results can be outstanding! Notice the way the simple frame on the left-hand edge of this shot helps create depth and lead the viewer toward the trees and sky in the background:

One tip: Consider whether you want the foreground frame to appear in focus or out of focus, and use either approach to your advantage. Both of these options will create very different images, and both require conscious effort. For in-focus foliage, you'll need to use a relatively narrow aperture, and you'll need to focus on a portion of the scene that's not too far from the nearest foreground elements. On the other hand, for out-of-focus foliage, you'll want to focus on a more distant subject, and you'll also need to use a relatively wide depth of field, such as f/2.8 or f/4, to ensure that the foliage is beautifully blurred.

Spring landscape photography: final words

At the end of the day, the most important technique for capturing great spring landscape photography is to just get out and take some pictures! Try out these tips and refine them with lots of practice; soon, you'll see your shots transform from mundane to magnificent. It won't happen overnight, but the more you get out in nature with your camera, the better your results will be.

现在交给你：

What are some of your favorite tips and tricks for great pictures of spring landscapes? Share your ideas and suggestions in the comments below!

The post 3 Handy Lighting Setups for Headshot Photography appeared first on Digital Photography School . It was authored by Dennis Drenner .

The post 3 Handy Lighting Setups for Headshot Photography appeared first on Digital Photography School . It was authored by Dennis Drenner .

If you're looking to get into the business of headshot photography – or you want to refine and expand your portfolio to make it more attractive to potential clients – then you must be capable of reproducing several basic lighting setups .

You don't have to be a lighting wizard, and you don't have to know dozens of sophisticated studio patterns. But a few basic setups can go a long way; they'll make your headshot images look refined and professional, and they'll also ensure that you have a few different options to make your clients look their best.

I do a lot of corporate and actor headshots around Washington, DC, and I wanted to share some of the simple but effective lighting setups that I use over and over again in my own work. Feel free to copy the headshot lighting setups that I suggest and use them to improve your photos!

1. The one-light wonder

My standard headshot lighting setup uses a single light source: one large, diffused strobe positioned to the left or right of the subject. I also add a reflector under the face, and I include another reflector opposite the main light source. I shoot hundreds of headshots per year using this simple setup.

I like to use a Paul C. Buff Einstein unit with a large octabox in my studio, but dedicated strobes and octaboxes can be expensive. You could easily put together something similar with a cheap speedlight, an umbrella, and a couple of $20 reflectors.

You can see this setup in the photo below, with my poor wife Karen standing in as a subject. She was just coming downstairs to make some tea and got ambushed!

Adjusting the angles and adding the reflectors

Once my subject is in place, I like to do some tweaking. First, I adjust the light source so it is slightly above the subject's eye level. For most people, I think it looks best to have the light coming from above so it can cast subtle shadows under the chin (this accentuates the jaw and helps to hide any double chins).

Then I adjust the reflector underneath the subject's face and bring it up to about mid-chest level. This reflector helps fill in shadows on the face and adds a really nice extra catch light in the eyes. Some headshot photographers prefer to use a second light source instead of the mid-chest reflector, but I find the reflector to be much simpler to set up, and it's also practically impossible to use incorrectly.

Why is a reflector so foolproof? If you have another light instead of a reflector below the subject and you accidentally overpower it (so it is more powerful than the main light), you'll end up with some horrible Frankenstein lighting! It's simply impossible to do this with a reflector – basic physics dictates that the strength of the light's reflection can never be greater than or equal to the strength of the original light – which can save you from costly mistakes.

Finally, I make sure to add the reflector opposite the light source. In the image of my studio above, you can see the naked reflecting panel, but I do sometimes like to tone this down a bit by adding a smaller, black-sided panel to create a darker shadow on that side of the face. Note the portable panel here, turned so that the black side faces my wife:

This effect can be very dramatic and has the added benefit of slimming the face. The downside is that, if your subject is very wrinkly, you're not filling those wrinkles with light from that side. So it doesn't work for everyone.

Here's an example of a headshot where I used this effect to create a nice dramatic edge:

But if you try out the darker panel and it doesn't work for your subject, don't be afraid to take it away and work with a pure white reflector.

A few additional tweaks for even better one-light headshots

With this simple setup, it's very easy to make tweaks and see what works best with a particular person's face. Often I will leave the basic setup in place with the black reflector, but here are a few times I might make changes:

  • The subject has a double chin, so I really want to define the jaw. In this case, I may raise the light up extra high to cast more shadow under the chin (making sure I don't go so high that I lose my catchlights), and/or lower or remove the reflector under the chin.
  • The subject has long, dark hair. In this case, the dark reflector is not necessary because we already have a dark edge from the hair. Instead, I would go with a white reflector on the side or bring in a hair light from behind (more on that in the next section!).
  • The subject has deep-set eyes. We want to fire more light into those sockets, or our poor subject will end up looking like a serial killer or a caveman! In this case, I might lower my light so it is right at eye level.

In the photo below, you can see a lot of detail in the subject's hair on the shadow side. That's because I brought my big white reflector in close.

2. The two-light headshot

You could run a whole headshot business using the one-light system, but if you're anything like me, you get bored and like to try new things. So let's bring in a second light.

The second light for me is usually a “kicker” (also called a rim or accent light ) that comes from behind and opposite the main light. I use this to accentuate the jaw, especially for men, or to accentuate the hair when doing headshots for women. It's especially nice for creating a little highlight on darker hair.

In the photo below, I needed a way to separate this young man from the dark background. My kicker light did the trick!

In my studio, I use a strobe with a stripbox for this purpose, but you could also use a bare strobe with a grid or even an old speedlight with a paper towel roll taped to it to make a simple snoot. The important thing is that you control the light so it doesn't spray into your lens and create flare or lack of contrast.

You can see my kicker light in this setup shot with Karen:

3. The three- or four-light headshot

I use lights three and four to create a clean white background . If you only own three lights, you can place the third one just behind the subject and fire it at the background; if you own four lights, you can place lights three and four on either side of the subject and fire them at the background together.

The white background is my favorite look these days, and that's for a lot of reasons. I think it looks super bright, modern, and happy. It also really pops on LinkedIn and other online profiles.

It's also a great option if you're doing corporate headshots for companies because it's easy to replicate and get a consistent look from shoot to shoot. This can be a big deal when your clients want similar-looking headshots for all of their employees and you won't be able to do all the headshots done on the same day.

For example, if you do an initial shoot and the company asks you a few months later to photograph a new employee, replicating the white-background effect will be far easier than trying to get the background color and brightness just right.

The white-background approach also makes it easy for you – or other photographers – to maintain the same look with shoots done across the country.

Anyway, whether you use one or two lights for the background depends on your budget and the space in which you are working.

Two lights can give you a larger, more even spread of light, whereas one light might create some fall-off (ie, darkness) around the edges that you need to clean up in post-production. So I usually stick to two lights. However, two lights also take up more space, so if I'm shooting on location somewhere and space is tight, I'll switch to one.

Create some beautiful headshots for your clients!

我希望这篇文章对您有所帮助！ Creating professional headshots doesn't have to be difficult; as I said, with a few simple lighting setups, you can satisfy pretty much any client.

And if you can't afford to work with multiple lights, a single speedlight and a couple of reflectors can work wonders!

So spend some time recreating the setups I shared above. Then use them to produce some amazing headshots for your clients!

现在交给你：

Do you have a favorite headshot lighting setup that you recommend? How do you plan to use the setups I shared? I'd love to hear from you in the comments below!

The post How to Photograph Through a Wire Fence (7 Effective Tips) appeared first on Digital Photography School . It was authored by Darren Rowse .

;

The post How to Photograph Through a Wire Fence (7 Effective Tips) appeared first on Digital Photography School . It was authored by Darren Rowse .

If you come across an interesting subject that's surrounded by a wire fence, then getting a good shot can be a real pain. This is a challenge most often faced at the zoo, but I've run into similar problems when photographing at pet stores, as well as when shooting old buildings (where the buildings had beautiful facades but were surrounded by wire fencing).

Really, you never know when you might need to photograph through a wire fence, and you can find yourself struggling in the most unexpected of circumstances (for example, I recently photographed some kids on a trampoline, which had mesh around it).

Now, you can't always eliminate the fence entirely from your composition, depending on the size of the fence wires, the size between the wire gaps, the distance to the subject, and your equipment. However, there are always ways to minimize the fence's impact, even if it doesn't seem like it – and there are also ways to approach fenced-in subjects so you have an easier time focusing.

So how do you take good photos through a wire fence? Here are a handful of my best tips:

1. Switch to manual focusing

When you're shooting through any kind of fence, especially if the material is especially noticeable or somewhat far away from your lens, your camera may not know what to focus on – the fence or the object behind it.

If you switch to manual focus mode , you'll be in complete control of what is in and out of focus, and you can carefully set your plane of focus so your main subject looks tack-sharp.

2. Get close to the fence

The best way to eliminate a fence from your images is to make the fence so out-of-focus that it's imperceptible.

One strategy is to get up very close to the fence – so close that the fence wire turns into an unnoticeable blur.

It may not be possible to get right up against the fence (when you're shooting a lion at the zoo, for instance, you may encounter other barriers in place for your own safety), but the closer, the better.

3. Use a large aperture

Getting close to the fence will cause it to blur, but if you can widen your lens's aperture as far as it can go – to f/4, f/2.8, or even f/1.4 – the depth of field will be narrowed, and the wire will be rendered even more out of focus.

Note that the longer your focal length, the shallower the depth of field. So if you use a telephoto lens and you shoot at an aperture of f/2.8, the fence will be blurrier than if you photograph with a wide-angle lens at f/2.8.

4. Wait until your subject is away from the fence

This won't help when you're photographing fenced-off buildings or landscapes, but if your subject is moving around behind the fence (such as a monkey at the zoo), wait until they're a little further back to take a shot 。

The closer they are to the fence, the more the fence will be in focus – but the farther back they go, the more the fence will blur (assuming your subject is in focus!).

5. Position your lens to shoot through larger gaps

This one isn't rocket science, but it's important to consider the size of the fence gaps. If the openings are large, you'll do better to position these gaps in the middle of your frame.

It can also help to examine the fence for any areas that might have larger gaps, and then adjust your position so these are included in your shot. (Of course, don't do this if it'll compromise safety; the goal is to get a clear shot, not to get close to your subject in a way that's dangerous.)

6. Avoid reflections and highlights on the wires

If you're shooting through a relatively reflective fence on a sunny day, you may notice reflections from the sun. (This can also happen when shooting metal fences at night, assuming there are bright streetlights or car headlights around.)

These reflections can be very noticeable, even if you manage to blur out the fence metal fairly effectively. Therefore, try to find a part of the fence that's shaded, or change your camera angle until the reflections disappear. (Another option is to get someone to stand in a way that casts a shadow on the fence!)

7. Incorporate the fence into your composition

You don't always have to eliminate fences from your shots. Sometimes I like to actually include in-focus fences in my compositions, so if you're struggling to shoot through a fence, why not try to use it creatively?

For instance, you can let the fence wires create interesting leading lines, or you can take a few steps back and capture the fence plus your subject. Fences don't always make for bad photography!

Go photograph through some fences!

Fences often seem like a huge photographic problem. However, I've shot through plenty of fences, myself, and I assure you that they're not as bad as you might think.

Just take steps to blur the fence so it's not visible. And if you can't blur the fence, then try to work with it to create an even more powerful photo.

So the next time you come across a fence, just remember the tips I've shared, and see if you can get some good shots!

现在交给你：

Do you have any additional tips for photographing through fences? Do you have any example photos to share? We'd love to hear from you in the comments below!

The post How to Edit Corporate Headshots in Lightroom appeared first on Digital Photography School . It was authored by Tim Sullivan .

When it comes to making people look their best in corporate headshot photography, you should certainly start with lighting, exposure, and composition. However, even if you're on top of your headshot photography game, there are plenty of small adjustments you can make in the editing process that'll make your photos (and your clients!) look far […]

The post How to Edit Corporate Headshots in Lightroom appeared first on Digital Photography School . It was authored by Tim Sullivan .

;

The post How to Edit Corporate Headshots in Lightroom appeared first on Digital Photography School . It was authored by Tim Sullivan .

When it comes to making people look their best in corporate headshot photography, you should certainly start with lighting, exposure, and composition. However, even if you're on top of your headshot photography game , there are plenty of small adjustments you can make in the editing process that'll make your photos (and your clients!) look far more professional.

To start, it's important to recognize that, on the day of the shoot, a lot of things will be out of your control. This is true whether you're a complete newbie – or a seasoned pro.

Take a booking I had recently. It was scheduled for a Friday afternoon, and it happened to follow a full week of annual strategy meetings. All the head honchos were dead tired, and looking good for photos was the last thing on their to-do list. After a week of deciding the future of their company, a lot of them looked a little….less than fresh. Dehydration, bags under the eyes, and coffee-stained teeth were starting to appear – because we're human and that's what happens. And although I knew that soft light would help, I also knew that cameras are rather unforgiving of the sleep-deprived.

This is an extreme example, but there are always minor aesthetic problems that you'll face as a headshot photographer. Fortunately, in every case, post-processing can come to the rescue. It'll make you feel better about your photos, and it'll make your subjects feel better about themselves. Although most of my corporate headshot clients know that post-production doesn't mean they'll end up as Heidi Klum, they do appreciate just a smidge of help once the photos are loaded up.

Corporate touch-ups are about making the subject look as fresh as can be. However, a post-processing workflow doesn't need to take hours. I like to keep my post-processing efficient, effective, and easy – so I can get the photos off my computer and onto my clients' desks as quickly as possible. Below, I explain how I edit my corporate headshots in Lightroom, using the streamlined workflow I've developed over the years. Specifically, I explain how you can take an unprocessed photo like this:

And, with a bit of editing, get a result like this:

(Note: While I certainly recommend Lightroom for your own post-processing needs, you can easily recreate my headshot editing workflow in Photoshop, Capture One, ON1 Photo RAW, and more.)

The Lightroom workflow I use for corporate headshots

The workflow I'm about to show you will suit a variety of corporate clients. But I'm going to use a single example photo from a professional photoshoot I did a few years back; that way, you can see my approach in action.

Let's start with the shot straight out of camera:

This particular company wanted to feature their employees in their native work environment, so the office became the background, which eliminated the need to bring a backdrop. I lit the subject with window light, an octabox, and a reflector, and I shot the image with a 50mm lens.

(Normally, I'd grab my 85mm for corporate work, but we were out of town and didn't have our full complement of gear with us. The 50mm did the job just fine, however!)

Step 1: Make basic exposure, white balance, and compositional adjustments

As soon as I pull up an image in Lightroom, I start by considering some simple adjustments:

Cropping, lens corrections, exposure, and white balance .

Not all of these adjustments are needed in every case, but it's always worth thinking about each one before moving on. Here, I need to crop the reflector out of the frame, as it's intruding on the left-hand side. If you look carefully at the vertical lines on the right-hand side, you'll notice some barrel distortion caused by my lens (the wall is curving slightly inward). Fortunately, this is easy to fix by checking the Enable Profile Corrections box in Lightroom's Lens Corrections panel.

I'm happy with the white balance in this image, but I do want to boost the exposure – the unedited file is a little dark – while also dropping the Highlights slider to prevent the brightest parts of the image from getting out of hand.

After making those adjustments, here's how the headshot looks:

Hopefully, you'll agree with me that it's much improved. Those minor tweaks refined the composition while making the scene feel tonally balanced. However, there's still more work to be done:

Step 2: Make local adjustments

Local adjustments are targeted to a specific part of the image, and while you can spend hours carefully retouching your subjects' features, the changes I make are subtle.

In truth, the best way to get some of these effects is to have the client get a great night's rest and stay hydrated, but as I said at the beginning of this article, that's mostly out of your control. And again, these adjustments aren't meant to turn anyone into an airbrushed masterpiece; they're designed to give your corporate clients a small boost.

Before we dive in, let's review some local adjustment keyword shortcuts to help you speed things up:

Adjustment Brush keyboard shortcuts

  • Press H to hide or show the pin you're using. This is helpful when the pin is in the way and you want it to disappear.
  • Press O to hide or show a mask overlay of the Brush's effect; you can also check the Show Selected Mask Overlay option in the Masking panel. This is helpful so you can see exactly what areas you're affecting. (Repeatedly tapping Shift+O will run through the overlay colors: white, black, red, and green).
  • Press Ctrl+Z (Windows) or Cmd+Z (Mac OS) to undo your most recent adjustment.
  • Hold Alt to turn the Brush into an Eraser. This will help you clean up any minor mistakes you make while adding adjustments.

Okay, now that we've got that out of the way, here are the local adjustments I make to my corporate headshots (and in this order, too):

1. Soften Skin

This helps clear up pores and deals with any blemishes. These are the settings I add to my Adjustment Brush in Lightroom :

  • Clarity: -50
  • Sharpness: -10
  • 对比度：+5
  • Highlights: +15 (to counteract the loss of highlights that comes from decreasing the Clarity slider)

I brush over the subject's entire face with the exception of the eyes, eyebrows, and lips. Since I like to use a green mask overlay, when I'm finished, my subject's face is fully Hulkified:

As mentioned in the previous section, you can change the color of the mask overlay by tapping Shift+O . These days, red is the default, but I use green as it's nice and easy to see.

If you make a mistake while softening the skin and go over any of the areas you don't want to target, just use the Alt key to turn the Brush into an eraser, then paint the mask away.

2. Diminish lines

I use this edit to soften any shadows created by wrinkles and smile lines, Here are the settings I apply with my Brush:

  • Contrast: -30
  • Shadows: +15
  • Clarity: -50
  • Sharpness: -10

Note that I keep the Brush small and soft as I paint across any lines on the person's face:

Let's look at the before and after of what we have so far (focusing on the local adjustments):

You'll see that the skin is more even throughout, and the deep shadows of the lines are reduced and softened (but not removed completely). Remember, the goal is to freshen , not to make the subject look like a plastic doll.

Next up, let's get those eyes popping a little more. This is easy to overdo, so be judicious.

3. Brighten the eyes

Slight adjustments to your subject's eyes will make them look more lifelike and animated. I like to start by brightening up the entire eye with these Brush settings:

  • Exposure: +0.2
  • Contrast: +10
  • Clarity: +10

As you can see, I've applied the mask to both eyes, taking care to cover the whites, the irises, and the pupils:

4. Enhance the iris

Once I've brightened up the eyes more generally, I like to focus on just the colorful part of the eye: the iris. I'll generally add a bit of positive exposure and a touch of saturation, as well as a few other minor adjustments to help the irises stand out:

  • Exposure: +0.40
  • Contrast: +20
  • Highlights: +35
  • Clarity: +5
  • Saturation: +20

Let's check back in with another before-and-after comparison:

It's subtle, but there's just enough pop around the eyes without it being overdone.

5. Whiten the teeth

It's time to make your subject's dentist proud! This is another adjustment you'll need to be careful not to overdo, and the specifics will depend on your subject's teeth, but here's what generally works for me:

  • Temp: -25 (adding blue gets rid of any yellow in the teeth!)
  • Exposure: +0.25
  • Saturation: -20

I carefully paint over the enamel while avoiding the lips and gums:

6. Define the hair and eyelashes

Now for the final touch, where I give a bit of definition to the hair and eyelashes. Here are the settings I like to apply:

  • Contrast: +10
  • Highlights: +20
  • Shadows: -10
  • Clarity: +30
  • Saturation: +10
  • Sharpness: +30

I'll paint over my subject's hair and eyelashes, and I'm careful not to accidentally enhance their skin – though I don't worry too much about brushing every single bit of hair:

包起来

That's pretty much all I do to enhance my corporate headshots! Let's take a final look at the before-and-after images after I've made my local adjustments:

And here's the photo that was delivered to the client:

All of these changes are delicate. When done right, they're almost imperceptible.

Remember: Retouching your corporate headshots doesn't need to be an hours-long endeavor. Your clients don't need to be on the cover of Vogue – they need a no-fuss photo that's LinkedIn-ready and that shows them at their best.

With the small edits I shared above, you can ensure that your headshot clients are satisfied by your work, and keep your portfolio looking polished!
